text: The moment I burst out from the shield wall, the snow beneath my feet suddenly felt hollowed out. It wasn’t a slip—it was a collapse.
The Demon King’s ‘breathing’ made the ground heave like something alive. I stepped into empty space; my knee slammed into jagged ice so hard my vision flashed white.
I tried to get up, tried to shout those words—but the whisper of black mist drilled into my ears first. It wasn’t a sound. It was an order.
“Come—back—.” The two words crawled against my throat like an icy hand clamping down on my airway.
I opened my mouth, but only a broken puff of white breath came out. The vow never took shape—like an unlit match snuffed out by the wind.
The Demon King tilted its head. It wasn’t drawn to me—it had simply noticed the ‘extra person.’
The instant its gaze landed, my whole body felt pinned in place. Not fear—something worse: a sick, familiar certainty, as if it had watched me fail in countless loops.
The black mist tightened violently. No more hesitation, no more lag—like a tide turning back to bite.
I saw Alicia’s fingers tremble again—and this time it wasn’t just fatigue. It was the last of her strength being stolen by that half-second we’d missed.
Alicia breathed out softly, “…Don’t come out.”
She finally looked back at me. There was no blame in it—only a calm forced to the edge of collapse, like she was pushing me back from death.
She had no time to hesitate. The necklace was in her hand, the core was right there—yet the black mist had already wrapped itself around her wrist again.
She forced the necklace toward the fissure in the core—yet this time the crack seemed to ‘close.’ Black light surged, biting down on the pendant like a living thing.
The Demon King’s claw came down. It wasn’t a slash—it was a ‘reset,’ pressing her back into the rift, snapping the loop back into alignment.
Alicia braced and blocked. Her shoulder guard burst under the pressure; blood seeped along her bracer and dripped onto the snow, turning it dark.
She still stepped forward—forcing herself even closer. That was always her way: trading life for an opening.
But this time, there was no opening.
The black mist suddenly recoiled, like countless icy chains coiling around her throat, wrists, and ankles. Her body was yanked up—hung in front of the core.
Her sword fell into the snow with a dull thud. That sound was clearer than any scream.
Alicia’s lips moved. It looked like she wanted to say something—an order for me to fall back, an apology, or… a farewell she’d finally have time to speak.
But the black mist cut off every word. Her eyes were still bright—until their focus began to slip away.
The Demon King pressed her toward the rift. It wasn’t tearing—it was erasure: like wiping a person clean out of the world.
In the next second, Alicia’s figure was swallowed by black light, along with the necklace—vanishing so completely it was as if she had never been there.
The wind went still for a heartbeat. Not because the wind had stopped—because the world itself seemed to have lost its breath.
I heard a sound tear out of my throat—something that didn’t feel human.
I tried to run to her, but my legs were filled with lead. Someone behind the shield wall shouted my name, but I couldn’t hear them.
The barrier’s blue light began to shatter—glass breaking into piece after piece. The soldiers’ breathing turned into panicked, ragged gasps.
The core in the Demon King’s chest lit up again. The light no longer churned—it became steady, as if proclaiming: the loop continues.
Black mist spread into a tide, rolling over the snow and swallowing the shield line. The city wall groaned as if it were breaking.
A cold emptiness flooded my chest, like the world had sentenced me to death. As darkness swallowed my vision, I had only one thought left—this time, I didn’t get to wait for her.
